title: Second Grade: Foundations of Social Studies – People and the Environment
subject: Social Studies (2021-)

document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

970C240957534815976744071A23AEAD.description:
Explore the importance of first peoples’/Indigenous peoples’
interactions to land, water and the nonhuman world.

3B04038CA2E5486888E193D13B0C558C.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

8FF07489F25248FBB7CD43FF3B4C15F7.description:
Describe how a community may consist of multiple cultures,
identifying how power is shared among cultural communities.
Identify power, cooperation and conflict in multicultural
communities.

23428A27F85F4179AD3963BE3F8625CD.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

6C7D4243DD24454AB376C969C6F819C4.description:
Propose an idea to improve the relationship between humans
and the environment.

48AA567CF858445C8CDC485EC02110B9.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

B320CA645D4348558E9D28E5F98A2913.description:
Identify how different groups have worked to protect the land
and natural resources.

2990A2BFC0B14D82BD19777F95D07341.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

33881718B4494BF1849F60A93B658EDF.description:
Compare and contrast different ways of knowing, seeing, and
understanding land use, rights, and ownership over time.

CCA30E2E903840D2B6242CDDED181D76.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

EF7FA10AEF6E4F83BFB4BC707FBE7DBD.description:
Use and create calendars to identify days, weeks, months, years
and seasons. Identify how the environment can impact how we
measure time and create calendars.

C7F263DE9A204D768EE3934F714285BF.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

DDBDF7D3A1DF4769B183F7F8CA47CF9E.description:
Use historical sources to investigate how the relationship
between people and the environment has changed over time.
Identify whose voices and perspectives are represented in the
sources and whose are absent.

17127BB34D3548FBA650F49D2B7796A8.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

4ABCE25C319A443EA70E9C160D79848D.description:
Describe how the culture of a community today reflects the
history, daily life or beliefs of its people.

DD8037A63771458CB64FECDAAAA4D36C.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

63378A6791C748BF9B15FB74230EAD69.description:
Describe daily life for Minnesota Dakota or Anishinaabe peoples
in different times, including before European contact and today.

2CA1084345BB4C119B343664C14997E2.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

23FD61A9DFE74D01B38DD4732920C49C.description:
Describe ways that the local environment influences people and
their actions and how human actions impact the local
environment, including air, water, land and wildlife.

4E4C1FC96D0241F1B2F084E2E3A95543.description:
Human-Environment
Interaction: Evaluate the
relationship between humans
and the environment, including
climate change.

A0A3CF83EAE44A5194599A309A834FE3.description:
Ask and answer spatial questions about physical and human
characteristics in the environment.

E72CBFDE0BE14B818604B64E782F96B4.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

C702EE5290234BB5A71F4CC3EFCF59B1.description:
Create sketch maps and use these, as well as fixed and dynamic
maps, to locate places. Describe locations on these maps in
relation to other places.

64FD5BC517E04E688E8D7798568A3A30.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

8BCF7B3563014324A97367CF9EE65236.description:
Given a goal and several alternative choices to reach that goal,
select the best choice and explain why.

CB8D5797F8B24E92972FF03588536013.description:
Personal Finance: Apply
economic concepts and models
to develop individual and
collective financial goals and
strategies for achieving these
goals, taking into consideration
historical and contemporary
conditions that either inhibit or
advance the creation of individual
and generational wealth.

74A6E94934604EC986D66A8B75B777B7.description:
Provide an example of an opportunity cost, which is the next
best alternative when a choice is made.

BF9DE0B080EF41DF9905A7B0A7464C59.description:
Fundamental Economic
Concepts: Analyze how scarcity
and artificial shortages force
individuals, organizations,
communities, and governments
to make choices and incur
opportunity costs. Analyze how
the decisions of individuals,
organizations, communities, and
governments affect economic
equity and efficiency.

73D9D2411960406ABF915353F9A3B4BA.description:
Investigate what characteristics allow an item to function as
currency.

ED5A850C9E71498E8A33DAC4FEA26AB1.description:
Economic Inquiry: Use
economic models and reasoning
and data analysis to construct an
argument and propose a solution
related to an economic question.
Evaluate the impact of the
proposed solution on various
communities that would be
affected.

30F14A4B50D94FE88BA07E2364C5DB03.description:
Describe how tribal government structures govern the affairs of
the nation.

218127B7DD4F4DBA9E86671DAA0318FB.description:
Tribal Nations: Evaluate the
unique political status, trust
relationships and governing
structures of sovereign Tribal
Nations and the United States.

18F392F5CB7A4D278ECB5C5D9E5B7E3E.description:
Identify a level of government and describe the role it serves in
the lives of community members.

E0594A29D0BA4F87841F42B6A42182E5.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

545C10EBBC16428BB2FE0B5AC606B635.description:
Compare and contrast student rules, rights and responsibilities
at school and at home. Explain the importance of following
rules. Discuss what to do when a rule is not fair.

89361945AEBA40F88A37007E46E6893B.description:
Rights and Responsibilities:
Explain and evaluate rights,
duties and responsibilities in
democratic society.

1E105042222F46D4B3EDE775AA6F6A77.description:
Describe how voting and elections exemplify democratic
principles, including, but not limited to, equality, freedom,
fairness, respect for individual rights, citizen participation,
majority rule and accepting the results of an election.

58F753A82AFC40429B1223A071F06805.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.

3D929F31D5DE4484AE1D9E08F79A3CE2.description:
Demonstrate voting skills by participating in a vote and
identifying the rules that keep the voting process fair.

24803651625E43E0ADF2498EA7D512B6.description:
Civic Skills: Apply civic
reasoning and demonstrate civic
skills for the purpose of informed
and engaged lifelong civic
participation.
